headline: Build Your Own  Election Map
summary: Think you know how the presidential vote will go? Use this tool to project the outcome for different states, then save and share the resulting election map.

headline: CD Yields Unchanged
summary: Yields on certificates of deposit were unchanged in the latest week.

headline: Valentino Spring 2013
summary: A look at the spring collection

headline: A Cost-Cutting Car
summary: In a bold move into the auto industry's fast-growing category of emerging-market countries, Nissan plans to revive its Beatles-era Datsun. Compare features for standard and 'bare bones' Datsuns.

headline: What's News: World-Wide
summary: What's News: World-Wide Top Stories for Oct. 1, 2012

headline: What's News: Business & Finance
summary: What's News: Business & Finance Top Stories for Oct. 01, 2012

headline: Ibanez Keeps Yanks in Front
summary: The veteran slugger delivers in the ninth and 12th innings to help the Bronx Bombers maintain a one-game division lead over the Orioles heading into the last day of the regular season.

headline: Dickey Reveals He Pitched With Torn Abdomen
summary: The Mets knuckleballer isn't his best against the Marlins on Tuesday, but does well enough to preserve his Cy Young Award-quality numbers.

headline: Maldives Lawmaker Stabbed to Death
summary: A lawmaker whose party is part of the Maldives' ruling coalition was stabbed to death in his home Monday night.

headline: Jerry Brown's School Bailout
summary: A state rescue in Inglewood, California helps unions, not students.

headline: New Measures Seen as Boost for Business
summary: The City Council and the Bloomberg administration outlined a series of measures aimed at easing the regulatory burden on small businesses, including eliminating obsolete violations and reducing the potential for fines.

headline: Jets' Holmes Likely to Miss Rest of the Season
summary: Also: The Red Bulls appoint a new GM, and Raymond Felton says he expects to play alongside fellow Knicks point guard Jason Kidd this season.

headline: Jobs Return to Stamford, With Assist
summary: For the fourth time in less than two years, Connecticut's chief job-creation program is helping a large company move to or expand in Stamford, a center of white-collar office culture in a state that has yet to fully recover from the recession.

headline: Death of American Van as Styling Goes European
summary: Ford will say goodbye to its E-Series vans, ending a half century of selling truck-based vans to tradesmen, families and hippies, as it releases more fuel-efficient and compact vans.

headline: Animal Activist Seeks Tyson Board Seat
summary: The head of the Humane Society is seeking a board seat at Tyson in order to press the food processor to phase out hog gestation stalls.

headline: Nets Calling on Brooklyn Dodgers
summary: Everything about the Brooklyn Nets seems brand new this season: new roster; new logo; new arena. But the Nets also have been doing some digging into the past.

headline: Social Security Pays Out More Than It Takes In
summary: Social Security paid out more than it collected in tax revenue in 2011, the second straight year that was the case, according to a Congressional Budget Office report that projects the gap will continue widening.

headline: Carlyle Buys Majority Stake in Commodities Trader
summary: Caryle has acquired a majority stake in commodities trader Vermillion in a deal financed in part by the private-equity firm's new currency: its publicly traded shares.

headline: The Pop Scene: The Flame-Thrower Heads North
summary: Waka Flocka Flame, Animal Collective, Blondie, Beth Orton and more highlight this week's Pop Scene.

headline: Los Angeles Reverses Pot-Shop Ban
summary: Repeal of Los Angeles's ban on storefront medical-marijuana dispensaries leaves as many as 1,000 pot shops all but unregulated.

headline: Will Obama Duck 'Won't Back Down'?
summary: ONLINE EXTRA: A Hollywood drama gives Mitt Romney an opening to challenge the president's school-reform credentials.

headline: Cornell Gets U.S. Hand
summary: The new class of Cornell University engineering students in the city will soon be getting entrepreneurial advice from an unlikely source: The federal government.

headline: Chiquita Brands Names Lonergan as CEO
summary: Chiquita Brands has chosen Edward Lonergan as its new CEO, succeeding Fernando Aguirre. He starts work on Oct. 8.

headline: Border-Patrol Agent Slain in Arizona
summary: A U.S. Border Patrol agent was killed and another was wounded Tuesday in a shooting in Arizona near the Mexican border.

headline: Bloomberg Donates to Tanzanian Project
summary: New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg said Tuesday his philanthropy will invest in an expansion of a maternal health program in Tanzania.

headline: The Young Trying to Help the Very Young
summary: As the youngest partner at health-care focused investment-management firm Deerfield Management, Alex Karnal, 30 years old, wanted to energize a new generation of philanthropists.

headline: Gramercy Club Anoints a New Era of Players
summary: Playwright Edward Albee was one of 14 inducted into the Players Hall of Fame at the Players Club, the elegant old institution on Gramercy Park South.

headline: Einhorn Takes on Chipotle
summary: The Greenlight Capital boss recommended GM and Cigna while panning Chipotle and repeating his disdain for Green Mountain Coffee, offering Wall Street more of the market-moving picks it has come to expect from the hedge-fund manager.

headline: Market Complexity Cited in Snafus
summary: Wall Street firms and exchanges should better police each other to prevent and reduce the cost of technology gaffes, industry executives and researchers told securities regulators Tuesday.

headline: Spectrum at Heart of T-Mobile/MetroPCS Deal
summary: The key attraction in the potential marriage of T-Mobile and MetroPCS is the ability to merge spectrum licenses, but history suggests combining airwaves can be tricky, especially when the technologies don't match.

headline: Departing Deutsche Bank
summary: The chief investment officer at Deutsche Bank's giant real-estate arm is stepping down at the end of the year, a bank spokeswoman said.

headline: Nurses Seek Expanded Role
summary: A federal agency is weighing whether to reimburse a specialized type of nurse for giving chronic-pain treatments, a move that critics say could complicate the battle against prescription painkiller abuse.

headline: So Much for the Yankees' Grand Plan
summary: Top pitching prospect Manny Banuelos needs Tommy John surgery and will miss the entire 2013 season—the latest setback to the team's efforts to control payroll.

headline: Google Withdraws Patent Claim Against Apple
summary: Google's Motorola Mobility has withdrawn a patent-infringement claim against rival Apple that was filed with the U.S. International Trade Commission in a bid to ban the import of some Apple products.

headline: Trudeau's Son Seeks Liberal Helm in Canada
summary: Justin Trudeau, the son of one of Canada's longest-serving prime ministers, on Tuesday night launched plans to lead the country's Liberal Party, potentially shaking up the political landscape of a country more recently dominated by Conservative leader Stephen Harper.

headline: Iran Blames Rial's Fall on Rogue Traders, Sanctions
summary: Iranian officials lashed out over the free fall of the rial, which lost nearly 25% against the dollar in just a week, by blaming illegal trading rings and fiscal mismanagement, and conceding that international sanctions have hurt its economy.

headline: Former Coach Sues Penn State for Defamation
summary: Mike McQueary, who was a key witness in the Jerry Sandusky child-sex-abuse trial, claimed Pennsylvania State University officials discriminated against him. .

headline: Winner Urges Georgia Leader to Quit
summary: Bedzina Ivanishvili, the once-reclusive banking billionaire who is now likely to become Georgia's next prime minister, marked his electoral victory by calling for the resignation of President Mikheil Saakashvili.

headline: U.S. to Buy Prison Once Slated for Gitmo Inmates
summary: The Justice Department is buying a prison in Illinois for $165 million, defying Republican lawmakers who have sought to block the purchase of the facility, earlier slated to be the new home of Guantanamo Bay prisoners.

headline: Fred Barnes: Romney's Dangerous Game of Playing It Safe
summary: The Republican needs to tap into voters' sense of urgency. Simply being Not Obama isn't enough.

headline: Cyrus Vance: Law Enforcement in the Age of Twitter
summary: How police, prosecutors and tech companies must cooperate in solving 21st century crimes.

headline: Money-Fund Reboot
summary: New support for reform should make the industry rethink its opposition.

headline: Allysia Finley: A Winning Plan for Ending Sports Lockouts
summary: Mr. President: To secure your re-election, ensure that pro athletes and refs stay on the job. Trust me.

headline: Jenkins: Obama, Romney and the Hail Mary
summary: The Fed, seeming to give up on politicians, is trying to heal U.S. debt wounds with a dose of inflation.

headline: A Scuffed iPhone 5
summary: Walt Mossberg answers readers' questions on the iPhone 5 and iOS 6.

headline: James Kirchick: A Russian Victory in Georgia's Parliamentary Election
summary: Billionaire winner Bidzina Ivanishvili owes his wealth to the Putin regime in Moscow.

headline: Rafael Reif: What Campuses Can Learn From Online Teaching
summary: Searching for the sweet spot where cyberstudents around the world pay a small fee that helps make the 'residential' college more affordable.

headline: Notable & Quotable
summary: An excerpt from the Telegraph obituary of British historian Eric Hobsbawm, who died Oct. 1 at age 95.

headline: Pope's Ex-Butler Criticizes Detention
summary: The pope's former butler said he "betrayed" the pontiff by leaking Vatican documents, but tried to put the Holy See on the defensive, saying he was detained in a tiny, constantly lit room for more than two weeks while Vatican authorities questioned him.

headline: Make Mine a Single: The Rise of Stronger Spirits
summary: Distillers are rolling out a growing number of whiskies, rums, gins—even cognacs—with higher-than-normal concentrations of alcohol.

headline: A Hero's Humble Ethos
summary: When his grenade launcher failed, a Marine slew a Taliban fighter with a rock. James D. Hornfischer reviews "Into the Fire" by Dakota Meyer.

headline: In Final Prep, Candidates Debate 'Stand-Ins'
summary: Both the Romney and Obama campaigns have held intensive sessions aimed at anticipating any scenario or question that threatens to throw them off message when the cameras are rolling.

headline: A Company's Anti-BYOD Policy
summary: Sue Shellenbarger answers a question from an employee of a company that has a policy preventing workers from bringing their own devices to work.

headline: Enterprising Time for Tech IPOs
summary: Workday hopes the IPO market is back, or is simply counting on the fact that for some types of companies, it never slowed down.

headline: T-Mobile Redials America
summary: When you are in a hole, you usually stop digging. And yet T-Mobile USA, after failing to sell itself to AT&T, may be about to dig even deeper into the U.S. market: It is in talks to purchase prepaid mobile carrier MetroPCS.

headline: CEO of Electric-Car Network Steps Down
summary: Shai Agassi, founder of U.S. electric-car charging station start-up Better Place LLC, stepped aside as chief executive amid concern about mounting losses as cars tailored to the company's network enter pilot markets.

headline: AIG Advances in 'Systemically Important' Review Process
summary: AIG became one of the first big, nonbank financial firms to alert investors that it is in the latter stages of consideration by federal regulators to be deemed systemically important.

headline: FCPA: Extradition Is Hurdle in Prosecutions
summary: While successful in reaching multimillion-dollar settlements with companies under the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act, the government is struggling to bring corporate executives to trial on foreign-bribery charges.

headline: Replacing the Radiator a Decade In
summary: Jonathan Welsh answers a reader's question on getting a new radiator when a car is 10 to 12 years old.

headline: Another Scalia Vexes Regulators
summary: A son of Supreme Court Justice Antonin Scalia has made his own mark in court, specializing in arguments against the new wave of financial regulations.

headline: Name Game: Fund Firms Scramble
summary: As recent trademark disputes show, it's never clear which fund names are distinctive enough to be off limits to competitors.

headline: A Dress Rehearsal for Wednesday's Debate
summary: Two University of Denver students stood in for President Barack Obama and Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney at a dress rehearsal Tuesday for the first 2012 presidential debate, which will take place Wednesday.

headline: A Future Red in Tooth and Claw
summary: David T. Little's "Dog Days" wastes no time: A taut libretto and varied, original music deliver its grim story like a punch in the stomach.

headline: U.K. Speeds 4G Mobile Goal
summary: Superfast Internet on mobile phones and tablets will be widely available in the U.K. in the first half of next year—six months earlier than expected—after the government brokered a deal with the nation's four biggest mobile operators.

headline: Europe Jumps on Bank-Overhaul Bandwagon
summary: The U.S. has its "Volcker rule," the U.K. has its Vickers reforms. Now the European Union is belatedly jumping on the bandwagon.

headline: The Rockabilly Queen
summary: Wanda Jackson on hard times and adult life, and being Elvis Presley's girl.

headline: His Women Revealed Him
summary: New York's Neue Galerie shines the spotlight on a Modernist painter who has so far had little exposure outside of Switzerland.

headline: Brazil Real Closes Essentially Steady Versus Dollar
summary: Brazil's real closes virtually stable against the dollar after the Brazilian government signals a continued determination to keep its currency within a tight trading band, which reduces the impact of market moves world-wide.

headline: Georgia's New Opposition
summary: Saakashvili has bequeathed his countrymen a republic—if they can keep it.

headline: Photos of the Day: Oct. 2
summary: In today's pictures, a Moscow soccer fan shows pride, children celebrate Gandhi's birthday in India, a man tries to catch a train during a transit strike in Italy, and more.

headline: African Troops Enter Militant Stronghold
summary: African Union troops took full control of the Somali port city of Kismayo, capturing the last stronghold of the al Shabaab Islamist group in Somalia.

headline: YouTube Holds Key Place in Google's Social 'Spine'
summary: Google may start seeing use of its social network increase among at least one constituency: People who make a living from posting videos on YouTube.

headline: Euro Gains Narrow in Late Trade
summary: The euro gave back some of its gains against the dollar after Spain's prime minister indicated his administration will delay a decision on whether to seek a bailout from the European Union.

section: New York House of the Day
headline: A Divided Brooklyn Home Made Whole
summary: The owners of this five-bedroom Brooklyn brownstone converted it back to a single-family home with a renovation that integrated the old with the new.

headline: Stephens: Benghazi Was Obama's 3 a.m. Call
summary: Libya was a failure of policy and worldview, not intelligence.

headline: Treasurys Recover From Early Weakness
summary: Treasury bonds clawed back earlier losses and ended on a high note, extending the market's winning streak to a third straight session.

headline: Canadian Dollar Slightly Down
summary: The Canadian dollar ended slightly lower against the U.S. dollar, but remained in a close range as investors held off on taking bets on the Canadian currency ahead of a key labor report Friday.

headline: Josef Joffe: Merkel, Mario and the European Money Machine
summary: Why risk death at the polls if you can bribe your voters with cheap money?

headline: Midtown Lunch, Views Included
summary: Haven, the restaurant on the roof of the Sanctuary Hotel, is serving a $29 three-course lunch year round. (A tent will seal the open-air deck when the weather cools; until then, heat lamps warm diners on chilly days.)

headline: Madoff Employee Trial Set for October 2013
summary: A group of former employees of convicted Ponzi scheme operator Bernard Madoff will go to trial on criminal charges in October 2013, nearly five years since the massive fraud came to light, a judge ruled.

headline: Vanguard Drops MSCI Benchmarks for 22 Index Funds
summary: Vanguard cited cost as the main factor behind its decision to change benchmarks for 22 of its index funds to those provided by FTSE Group and the University of Chicago. MSCI shares plunged on the news.

headline: Gas Futures Rally for Sixth Day
summary: Natural-gas futures pushed higher, extending the rally in front-month futures to six straight sessions as investors bet on rising demand for gas-fired heating as colder weather approaches.

headline: Greater New York Property Watch

headline: Why Is the Euro So Perky?
summary: The simple explanation for euro's resiliency is that it stems from Mario Draghi's willingness to have ECB act as a lender of last resort. Yet, economic data from Europe have continued to worsen. We see riots in Greece and Spain and we wait for the Germans to coherently respond to this ongoing crisis.

headline: Emerging Market Currencies Mixed
summary: Emerging market currencies were mixed, with many paring their gains as concerns about the euro-zone debt crisis returned to market focus.

headline: Ex-Nokia Team to Launch New Phone
summary: Some former Nokia employees have raised $258 million to launch a mobile operating platform based on discarded Nokia technology, and the group will unveil a new phone next month.

headline: Primed for Growth: Shares of U.K. Asset Managers
summary: U.K. asset managers with exposure to emerging markets have been better placed than more narrowly focused rivals to weather an up-and-down year that has put fund returns and sales under pressure.

headline: Democratic Debate Advice for Mitt
summary: A former pollster for Bill Clinton and Al Gore says Mitt Romney should lay out bold policies to boost businesses and jobs.

headline: Why Chávez Backs Obama
summary: Sometimes it is hard to tell who Venezuela favors in the U.S. election.

headline: Court Sentences Abbott for Off-Label Promotion of Antiseizure Drug
summary: A federal court in Virginia formally sentenced Abbott Laboratories for its off-label promotion of its antiseizure drug Depakote, ordering it to pay $700 million as part of a previously announced $1.6 billion settlement.

headline: Why U.S. Golfers Should Cut Class
summary: It's fair to question whether college may be part of the problem—not just in golf, but in other world sports where the U.S. is suffering, including tennis and soccer.

headline: Feds Are Right on Hidden Accounts
summary: It is disingenuous at best to suggest that hiding funds overseas to avoid U.S. judgment creditors, i.e., a "drunk person stepping in front of your car," is a legitimate practice (Holman Jenkins's "Bradley Birkenfeld, Hero of Tax Reform," Business World, Sept. 15).

headline: Banks Like Munis; Mom-and-Pop Investors Don't
summary: Bankers are increasingly turning to municipal bonds to protect their profit margins from declining interest rates—just as mom-and-pop investors, the largest holders of such securities, are becoming more reluctant to buy them.

headline: Quitting Saves Lives, Money, Too
summary: Just how much does letter writer Stephen Helfer (Sept. 26), who notes smokers who quit often then spend more on food, think removing the lower right-hand lobe of my lung because of lung cancer caused by 35 years of smoking cost?

headline: Mourning the Fallen, Missing Lost Friends
summary: Your front-page story "A Marine's Death Brings Together His Dad and His Battlefield Buddy" (Sept. 22) is moving and at times painful, but it is also healing and redemptive.

headline: The Canadian Fisc and Reaganism
summary: While I find "How Canada Saved Its Bacon" by Mary Anastasia O'Grady (Americas, Sept. 24) enlightening, it understates the political conversion of the Canadian Liberal Party.

headline: Bayh Shouldn't Be Surprised by the Bad Tax He Passed
summary: Regarding "ObamaCare's Tax Raid on Medical Devices" (op-ed, Sept. 28): Former Sen. Evan Bayh is a rare Democrat who grasps that raising taxes on a product or service always has a negative effect on economic activity related to that good or service.

headline: The Sad Case of Stockton's Sellout by Its Politicians
summary: As I read City Manager Bob Deis pleas for relief from the city's "capital-markets creditors" in the Stockton, Calif., bankruptcy, I feel little compassion for the plight of the public worker and retiree's interests ("A Message From the City That Went Bankrupt," op-ed, Sept. 28)

headline: Singapore Gets a Makeover
summary: Rising up across 360 hectares of reclaimed land in downtown Singapore are a slew of new mega-developments with an unusual mix of entertainment and business.

headline: Bill Gross: Bonds Could Be 'Burned to a Crisp'
summary: The world's biggest bond fund, run by Bill Gross, took in $2.8 billion in new cash last month, even as he warned that bonds could be "burned to a crisp" if the U.S. doesn't tackle its debt problems.

headline: Chanel Spring 2013
summary: Karl Lagerfeld for Chanel at the Paris Fashion Week

headline: ArQule, Daiichi Sankyo End Cancer-Drug Trial
summary: ArQule and Daiichi Sankyo will discontinue their Phase 3 clinical trial on a drug to treat non-small cell lung cancer, after an independent committee concluded that the study wouldn't meet its primary goals of improved overall survival.

headline: Talanx Shares Close Above IPO Price
summary: Shares of Talanx closed 1.1% above their IPO price, allowing the German insurer to claim success after deciding to go ahead with the on-again, off-again deal.

headline: In Singapore, Focusing on Heritage
summary: Like most Asian cities, Singapore is known for paving over its past in favor of tall skyscrapers and mega-highways. But increasingly its residents and some developers are cashing in on the city-state's rich historical heritage, as a preservationist ethos spreads more widely in Asia.

headline: Righting London's Listing Reputation
summary: "Come one, come all" has been the U.K.'s message to companies wanting to list on London's stock market in recent years. Perhaps no more.

headline: Singapore's Home-Price Balancing Act
summary: Home prices in Singapore have kept surging almost without interruption since the global financial crisis, but some experts are starting to wonder how long the city-state's residential high-wire act can go on.

headline: GE to Call for Engine Inspections
summary: General Electric will tell aircraft operators to make another round of inspections on GE engines installed on Boeing's 787 and newest 747 models following an engine failure in Shanghai last month.

headline: Taiwan to Gain Visa-Free Travel to U.S.
summary: Taiwanese will be allowed to visit the U.S. without having to apply for a visa, after Homeland Security Secretary Janet Napolitano announced Taiwan's inclusion in the U.S. visa-waiver program from Nov. 1.

headline: Credit Suisse: These Downgrades Aren't Personal
summary: Credit Suisse downgraded 35 companies to "underperform"—but not because it was in a bearish mood. Instead, it is part of a broader shift in the way it rates companies.

headline: How to Win a Post-Steroids World Series
summary: Who is going to win the World Series? By analyzing the statistical performances of the World Series champions the past five years, it's not hard to come up with a profile for an eventual champion.

headline: Strauss-Kahn Rape Charges Dropped
summary: French prosecutors said they have dropped preliminary gang-rape charges against Dominique Strauss-Kahn because the alleged victim said she had consensual sex with the former IMF chief.

headline: Fox, Turner Reach MLB Deal
summary: Major League Baseball, as expected, reached long-term TV-rights agreements with Fox and Turner Sports, granting them eight-year contracts that will run through 2021. The World Series will remain on Fox.

headline: Mosaic Profit Off 18% Amid Lower Phosphate Volume
summary: Mosaic Co.'s earnings fell 18% as the fertilizer producer's sales declined because of production problems and weak demand in China and India.

headline: Rising From the Sea: Singapore's Marina Bay
summary: Out of reclaimed land, Singapore's newly-developed Marina Bay area is now home to one of the world's most profitable casino resorts, glitzy financial buildings and trendy new bars and restaurants

headline: Mongolia's Courage
summary: Corruption is a manageable challenge.

headline: Charlene Barshefsky: America's TPP Touchstone
summary: To grow, innovate. To innovate, protect intellectual property rights.

headline: European Stocks Slip Amid Spain Confusion
summary: European stocks fell slightly Tuesday, as investors grappled with mixed signals about whether Spain will request a bailout soon.

headline: Delta Air's Fuel Costs Drop
summary: Delta Air boosted the bottom end of guidance for third-quarter operating profits as its new refinery helped lower fuel costs, while bookings in the current quarter were solid.

headline: Tivo's Patent Need for Reinvention
summary: Has TiVo, the DVR pioneer, become little more than a patent play?

headline: Four Wall Street Obsessions You're Better Off Ignoring
summary: These four seemingly high-brow investment concepts offer a false sense of security and can do more harm than good. We present simpler, better alternatives.

headline: GASB Chairman Attmore to Retire Next Year
summary: The head of the Governmental Accounting Standards Board, which sets accounting rules for state and local governments, will retire next year.

headline: Juniper to Cut 5% of Workforce
summary: Juniper Networks said it will lay off about 500 employees to help meet next year's cost-cutting goals, reducing its workforce by about 5%.

headline: Dollar Resilient in the Face of QE3
summary: Having fallen to its weakest level since February, just a day after the Federal Reserve announced its hotly awaited third round of quantitative easing, the dollar is on the comeback trail, writes William Kemble-Diaz.

headline: South Africa Mine Union Seeks Talks
summary: South Africa's largest mine union said it will meet with the Chamber of Mines Wednesday in a bid to bring forward wage talks, a move it hopes will curb the spread of illegal strikes and mine violence.

headline: EU Panel Joins Call for Banks to Split
summary: A European Commission-appointed panel of experts recommended that banks should separate risky financial activities from deposits in a move that could lead to the breakup of large and systemic European financial institutions.

headline: Dialysis-Service Firm Says U.S. Inquiry Ends
summary: The U.S. attorney's office for St. Louis recently completed its investigation against DaVita and isn't taking any action against the company, according to DaVita.

headline: China Banks Pull Out of Japan Meetings
summary: Japan's territorial dispute with China appears to be spilling onto the stage of global finance meetings as several big Chinese banks say they're skipping meetings of the World Bank and the IMF in Tokyo next week.

headline: Overheard
summary: None

headline: Web Rivals Want What Google Got
summary: Google received multiple incentives to build its Kansas City ultra-high-speed fiber network. Now, Time Warner Cable and AT&T, the incumbent Internet and TV providers in town, are angling to get the same deal.

headline: Wiley to Buy Deltak.edu
summary: John Wiley & Sons is buying Deltak.edu, an online-education company, for $220 million.

headline: PVH Raises Profit Forecast
summary: PVH, formerly known as Phillips-Van Heusen, raised its per-share earnings guidance for the fiscal third quarter and year, reflecting continued strong performances at its Tommy Hilfiger and Calvin Klein brands.

headline: Express Cuts Outlook
summary: Young-adult clothing retailer Express cut its fiscal third-quarter guidance, pointing to an abrupt change in customer traffic during September.

headline: Canadian Dollar Mostly Flat in Quiet Trading
summary: The Canadian dollar continues to trade in a tight range against the U.S. dollar, opening Tuesday's session mostly unchanged as investors held off on making major moves.

headline: Boosting Success Rate of In Vitro Fertilization
summary: Fewer than half of women seeking help from a fertility clinic succeed at getting pregnant after their first treatment. Now, some researchers believe they have found a way to improve those odds.

headline: Ai Weiwei: Shutdown Is 'Face-Saving' Measure
summary: Dissident artist Ai Weiwei says a Chinese government decision to shut down a company controlled by his wife amounts to a likely effort by authorities to "maintain face" in their long-running battle with him.

headline: J-Power to Restart Work on New Nuclear Plant
summary: Japan's stated policy of eventually ending its dependence on nuclear power has suffered another apparent setback with the announcement that construction will restart on a nuclear plant in northern Japan.

headline: Kingfisher Cancels Flights Amid Strikes
summary: Kingfisher Airlines declared a "partial lockout" and canceled all flights through Thursday because of continued strikes and alleged agitation by some employees.

headline: FX GLOBAL CALL: Our Take on the Day's Big FX News
summary: The FX Global Call covers the main talking points from a news meeting involving DJ FX Trader editors in New York, London and Singapore, as well as other FX hot spots when warranted.

headline: Iran Currency Slides Further
summary: The Iranian rial is in freefall again, with a wide variety of rates being quoted on the beleaguered currency adding to the confusion.

headline: Inflation Rises in Rich Economies
summary: The annual rate of inflation across developed economies rose for the first time in a year in August, a development that may narrow the scope for central banks to shore up growth.

headline: Yields Will Still Lead Euro by the Nose
summary: While confusion reigns and the euro shows little real direction, the bottom line remains: if Spanish borrowing costs don't fall, the single currency will once again be at risk, writes Nick Hastings.

headline: Euro-Zone Factory Prices Accelerate
summary: The prices charged by euro-zone factories for their goods rose sharply in August, a development that could raise concern at the European Central Bank.

headline: South Korea Data Point to Rate Cut
summary: South Korea's consumer prices remained subdued in September, while manufacturing activity shrank for a fourth straight month, boosting expectations that the central bank will trim interest rates next week.

headline: S&P: Japan Growth to Slow
summary: Japanese economic growth is set to slow as the boost from reconstruction-related demand fizzles, ratings firm Standard & Poor's said in a report.

headline: RBA Rate Cut Lifts Sydney Shares
summary: Australian stocks led Asian markets Tuesday, ending at their highest level in five months after the country's central bank delivered a surprise interest rate cut. The S&P/ASX 200 rose 1.0%.

headline: Fledgling Mondelez Bets on 'Powerbrands'
summary: Mondelez, the snack-food spin-off from Kraft that will begin trading as a separate company, is betting on the power of global brands such as Toblerone and Cadbury chocolate to stay on the shopping lists of European consumers.
